abstract.p: Recent research has examined the importance of moral character assessment in social interactions, focusing on how individuals infer trustworthiness based on others' moral decisions, especially in sacrificial moral dilemmas. These dilemmas typically juxtapose utilitarian principles (harm for the greater good) against deontological ethics (inherent rightness or wrongness of actions). Extending previous work that relied on single-shot sacrificial dilemmas, we study trustworthiness inferences in iterative dilemmas involving multiple moral decisions. This approach addresses some of the limitations associated with prior work by considering the interdependency of moral judgments. In a series of five studies (N = 1234), we uncover robust evidence for a similarity effect in trust inference: people trust those whose moral preferences match their own. This similarity effect not only applies to consistent deontological or utilitarian choices but even extends to switching patterns across dilemmas. These findings challenge prior research that suggested that trust inference primarily favors deontological others.

In Similarity We Trust: Not the Type of Moral Judgment but Like-Mindedness Drives

div.head: Inferences of Trustworthiness
div.p: Our success in navigating the complexities of our social world greatly depends on our ability to quickly and accurately assess the moral character of the people we meet. Studies in social cognition suggest that one of the first elements we try to gauge in others is their intent to cause harm or provide help (Goodwin et al., 2014). Discerning the moral character of others is crucial, as it helps determine whom to trust.

Naturally, observable judgments or behaviors in the moral domain help signal moral character to others. In their seminal work, Everett et al. (2016) explored how people's perceptions of trustworthiness are influenced by how others respond to hypothetical moral dilemmas. Everett et al. (2016) focused on sacrificial moral dilemmas that present situations where inflicting harm serves the greater good, e.g. sacrificing one life to save many (Greene et al., 2004). Embracing harm to save a larger number of people in such cases is considered to be in line with utilitarian or consequentialist ethical principles that judge the morality of an action based on its consequences (Mill, 1861(Mill, /1999. Conversely, opposing harm in such dilemmas aligns with deontological ethics, which judge actions based on their inherent nature, viewing certain actions as inherently wrong regardless of their outcomes (Kant, 1959(Kant, /1785. Everett et al. (2016) found that people generally perceive those who reject sacrificial harm as more trustworthy than those who condone it. Building on this, further studies have shown that individuals who oppose harm for the greater good are often seen as more likable, friendly, and trustworthy (Bostyn & Roets, 2017;Brown & Sacco, 2019;Rom & Conway, 2018;Sacco et al., 2017;Smillie et al., 2021). Thus, deontological decisions, compared to utilitarian ones, are believed to convey stronger benevolent intentions, enhancing trust and desirability in social interactions and relationships.

However, not all studies have confirmed this general pattern. The moral preferences of the observer and the specific features of the dilemma can influence how trust is inferred. In certain situations, individuals might place their trust in someone who shows a deep commitment to fundamental moral rules, irrespective of the outcomes. In other contexts, there can be a preference for individuals who are characterized by their consideration of consequences.

Recent work by Bostyn et al. (2023) highlighted that the context of moral alignment and trust is largely understudied in the literature. This work investigated the robustness of previous findings while accounting for contextual effects (e.g., possible features of the situation described in the sacrificial dilemma). The work demonstrated that deontologists are not always trusted over utilitarians, but rather that trust inference depends on contextual factors, and most notably the similarity between the rater and the target, in their moral judgments: deontologists favored other deontologists and utilitarians favored utilitarians. We use the term 'similarity effect' in the current paper to refer to this effect. This key finding challenges previous findings in the literature, and suggests the importance of similarity may have been overlooked in previous work.

Although similarity effects have informed findings in other domains of psychology and sociology, such as interpersonal liking (Byrne, 1971;Byrne & Nelson, 1965) and social affiliations (McPherson et al., 2001), it has been conspicuously absent in moral psychology literature.

In the current research, we aim to expand our understanding of moral character assessment by broadening the scope of the moral dilemmas studied. Previous research primarily focused on trust inference based on moral judgment in the context of single-shot, sacrificial dilemmas. These dilemmas present scenarios and targets that involve making a decision on a single action, leading to trust assessments based solely on that decision. Findings based on single-shot sacrificial dilemmas treat moral decisions as isolated incidents, ignoring their interconnected nature and the broader context of recurring moral choices. In one attempt to address this lacuna, Bostyn and Roets (2022) argued for the need to study iterative sacrificial dilemmas, i.e., exploring how repeated moral decision-making scenarios might shift moral judgments. One-shot dilemma scenarios exclude the possibility that people might try to balance multiple moral concerns across multiple decisions, and that such a balancing act is meaningfully different from decisions that remain consistent within a moral principle (i.e., utilitarianism or deontology). With iterative sacrificial dilemmas, one can examine not only decisions driven by utilitarian or deontological principles, but also those influenced by a concern for the aggregate distribution of harm.

Consider this iterative dilemma: a device connected to six monkeys can deliver electric shocks. Five monkeys can avoid a distressing shock if it's redirected to the sixth. While not lifethreatening, this scenario mirrors the structure of traditional sacrificial dilemmas. But what if the dilemma repeats, and another shock will be administered? Does repetition lead individuals to consistently choose the same action? Bostyn and Roets (2022) show that when dilemmas involve the same subjects repeatedly, decision-makers often switch their choices to distribute the harm.

We build on Bostyn and Roets' (2022) by studying trust inference within the context of iterative dilemmas. This will help us to assess how trustworthy deontological and utilitarian decision-makers are perceived to be, and additionally, how trustworthy people that balance harms are perceived to be. The present work thus extends the literature in two important ways:

First, we consider how trust is inferred in the context of iterative moral decisions. Second, we explicitly consider and reevaluate the role of observers' own moral preferences on trust inference, i.e., to what extent does similarity in moral preferences between the observer and the target affect trust? We present two sets of studies, each focused on investigating trust inference. In Studies 1a,

1b, and 1c, participants were tasked with playing a series of trust games. In these trust games, participants received some information about the partner in these games: i.e., the choices the partner had made in an iterative dilemma. In Studies 2a and 2b, we again presented participants with a series of iterative dilemmas and directly probed them on how trustworthy they would rate others based on their responses to those dilemmas.

div.head: Open Practices Statement
div.p: Data, materials, and analysis code are available via OSF and can be accessed at (https://osf.io/tbjyp/?view_only=e3683ca79a82492db295bc2c5143a995). Studies 1a, 2a, and 2b were not preregistered 1 , but we preregistered Study 1b and Study 1c. The registrations can be found on the OSF page. All studies were conducted in accordance with the ethical protocol of the host institution's [institution anonymized for peer review] Ethical Committee.

div.head: Participants
div.p: For Study 1a, we recruited volunteers from the general population of a Western European country through social media. For Studies 1b and 1c, we recruited North-American participants from Amazon's Mechanical Turk through the CloudResearch platform, for participation in the 5-10 minute study. We recruited participants with a task approval > 90% but did not require a minimum number of prior tasks completed. Participants using suspicious geocode locations, and those with duplicate IP addresses were blocked from participation.
We did not exclude participants from Study 1a. However for Studies 1b and 1c, as per our preregistration (pre-registration link:

https://osf.io/tbjyp/?view_only=e3683ca79a82492db295bc2c5143a995), participants were excluded from the main analyses if they met at least one of the following criteria: they (1) they indicated a low proficiency in English (self-report < 5, on a 1-7 scale); (2) self-reported not being serious about filling in the survey (self-report < 4, on a 1-5 scale); (3) completed the survey too quickly (within 2 min); or (4) failed any of the two comprehension checks. We excluded 49 and 71 participants from Study 1b and Study 1c from the analysis based on the attention check questions (please see supplementary materials for details).

Basic demographic statistics and sample sizes for each study are available in Table 1. 237 (117,117,3) 42.38 (13.66) Note. Study 1b and 1c descriptive demographic information of the participants after the exclusion of responses based on the pre-registered exclusion criteria.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: In all three studies, participants first completed an iterative dilemma as a measure of their own moral preference. Subsequently, they were asked to play a series of trust games. Participants were explained how trust games worked and then played an uninformed trust game aimed at measuring participants' levels of baseline trust and cooperation. Participants then played a series of informed trust games, in which participants were provided with some information about their partner in the trust game: their decisions on an iterative sacrificial dilemma (for a similar procedure see Bostyn et al., 2023). Notably, the dilemma used to assess participants' moral preferences was different from those used in the trust inference tasks involving others.

All three studies used the same materials and confronted participants with the same dilemmas. Additionally, Studies 1b and 1c probed participants to rate warmth, competence, empathy, rigidity, courage, and willingness to experience discomfort to bring about greater good to others. The results of the additional measures mirror the results of the trust measure. For brevity's sake, we do not discuss these measures within the main text but the results are available through the online supplementary materials.

div.head: Moral Preference
div.p: In all three studies, participants' own moral preference was measured by confronting them with a single iterative dilemma taken from Bostyn and Roets (2022). The dilemma, also outlined in the introduction section, required participants to choose between allowing five monkeys to be shocked or redirecting the shock to one monkey across two iterations. While this second iteration is superficially the same as the first, the underlying moral conflict is changed by the prior context. Whereas on the first iteration, participants are torn between a deontological concern not to harm, and a utilitarian concern to minimize harm, the second iteration allows for a third type of decision: to balance the harm across all possible victims by responding differently to each iteration. Participants' moral preferences were classified as deontological or utilitarian when their preferences were consistent across two iterations of the dilemmas. When preferences changed between iterations this was classified as a switch preference.

div.head: Trust games
div.p: The study setup involved engaging participants in a sequence of trust games. Before beginning the initial game, the participants received a detailed briefing on the mechanics of the game. Specifically, it was clarified that each game would involve two roles: a trustor and a trustee. The trustor would start with an allocation of 10 credits and have the freedom to decide how many to transfer to the trustee. It was emphasized that any credits passed to the trustee would be increased threefold, and the trustee would then have the discretion to return any portion of these augmented credits. Therefore, trustors could potentially enhance their gains by entrusting a maximum number of credits to the trustee, albeit with the risk of loss if the trustee proved unreliable. The participants were informed they would engage in multiple rounds of the game, each time paired with a different participant. It was indicated that the games would not be played in real-time, but participants' choices would be paired with participants who completed the study previously. While participants were led to believe they might play in both the trustor and trustee roles, they assumed the role of the trustor in all rounds. After receiving all information regarding the trust games, participants completed two comprehension checks aimed at confirming they understood the nature of the task at hand.

div.head: Measures of trust and cooperation
div.p: In all three studies participants were asked to play a series of trust games. The participants in Study 1a did not receive any financial incentives to take part in the study, whereas Study 1b and 1c involved a fixed remuneration to complete the study. Additionally, in Study1b and 1c, to motivate participants to engage seriously with the trust games, they were informed of the possibility of earning a bonus ranging from $0.00 to $0.25 based on their choices in the scenarios. The determination of these bonuses was based on their responses in the initial trust game, where they were hypothetically paired with a trustee. The participant's reported trust directly determined the bonus paid out (ranging from 0$ to $0.25, with .05$ intervals, corresponding to the trust scale ranging from 1 to 5).

As a measure of their baseline levels of trust and cooperation, participants first played a single uninformed trust game. They were told that they were matched with a random other participant and received no further information about who this other participant might be.

Participants were asked to rate how much they trusted the (random) other player, using a fivepoint Likert scale spanning from (1) Not at all to (5) Completely, as well as how many credits they wanted to endow the other player with using a sliding scale spanning from 0 to 10 credits.

Afterward, participants completed a series of three informed trust games. On each of these trust games, participants were asked to read a (different) iterative sacrificial dilemma. Crucially, they were told how their partner in the trust game had responded to that dilemma. Across all three games, participants were confronted with a partner that had a) consistently chosen the utilitarian response, b) consistently chosen the deontological response, and c) switched their response from a deontological response in the first iteration to a utilitarian response in the second iteration. The partner's decision across the conditions was displayed in a similar manner, the decisions taken described for each iteration in bullet points (please refer to supplementary material section for details). Participants were asked to rate how much they trusted the other player, as well as how many credits they wanted to endow their partner with, using the same scales as on the uninformed trust game.

div.head: Results
div.p: We first looked at participants' own moral preferences, i.e. the pattern of their responses to the iterative dilemma (see Table 2). Participants' preferences were classified as 'Switch' when participants chose the deontological option in the first iteration of the dilemma and the utilitarian option in the second iteration, or vice versa. Only a small proportion of participants consistently choose the deontological response In Study 1a, a majority of participants can be categorized as "switchers", whereas in Study 1b and 1c, we found a balance between switch and utilitarian preferences.

div.head: Table 2
div.p: Participants' own moral preferences across two iterations of the sacrificial dilemmas All three studies included multiple judgments per participant. Accordingly, we conducted linear mixed-effects regressions using the lme4 package in R (Bates et al., 2015;R Core Team, 2023). We ran separate models for each study and each dependent variable (trust vs. credits endowed). All models included the type of choice favored by the trustee (Utilitarian vs.

Deontological vs. Switcher), a dummy factor coding for similarity with participants' own moral preference (Yes vs. No), and the interaction of these terms as predictors. As control variables, all models also included the baseline measurement of trust or cooperation, respectively. All models included Participant ID as a random intercept. Figure 1 provides a visual overview of the trust ratings and credits endowed in the three studies for the various cells in this design. We tested the overall effect of similarity by comparing these models to models that did not include the dummy factor for similarity and its interactions. Crucially, adding similarity to the models increased model fit in all three studies and on all dependent variables, all Χ2(3) > 16.24, all p ≤ .001.
Detailed statistical results are available in the supplementary materials.

Additionally, we conducted post-hoc pairwise comparison tests adjusted using the Tukey method. We observed significant differences between the levels of trust for and cooperation depending on the type of responses preferred by the targets. These effects are summarized in Figure 1 (see the supplementary section for the detailed results of post hoc comparisons). Across samples and dependent variables, we found that "deontologists" were trusted less than "switchers" and "utilitarians". In some instances, we found "utilitarians" were trusted more than "switchers", though this pattern was not consistent.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Inferred trust and cooperation as a function of partner judgment and participant-partner similarity in judgment.

Note. Annotations carry results of post hoc pairwise comparisons adjusted using the Tukey method. Annotations at the upper part of the plots carry comparisons across target type, and the annotations at the lower part of the plots report the similarity effect within each target condition.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: These first studies provide evidence for the similarity hypothesis. Although we did not uncover statistically significant differences in all individual comparisons, participants did clearly prefer partners displaying the same moral preference over partners displaying a dissimilar preference. This similarity effect is especially noteworthy given that participants' moral preference was measured through a different dilemma than the ones used in the trust games. This suggests, that the similarity effect does not only pertain to direct similarity (i.e., same answers on the same dilemma) but rather to 'moral principle' similarity across different dilemmas.

In addition to the similarity effect, the type of judgment displayed by the partner also appeared to have an impact. Interestingly, in contrast to prior work in this area (see Bostyn & Roets, 2017;Brown & Sacco, 2019;Everett et al., 2016), deontological partners were trusted the least. In this regard, it is worth noting that we did not try to balance the types of responses that people prefer when confronted with the dilemma included in these studies. Indeed, we used iterative dilemmas adapted from earlier work (Bostyn & Roets, 2022), and on these specific dilemmas, apparently only a small minority of participants favored a consistent deontological response (less than 14% across three samples). One possibility is that trust perceptions are not only driven by a similarity effect but also by a comparison to an assumed majority preference (i.e., norm). In other words, people might be more inclined to distrust others if a particular response is (perceived as) descriptively uncommon on the dilemma at hand.

We decided to run two more studies to address some potential shortcomings of Studies 1a-c. One potential limitation of these studies is that we used a different dilemma to probe participants' own moral preference as we did to probe trust ratings. While the responses to the initial dilemma indicate a commitment to a particular moral concern, they do not necessarily reflect the specific moral preference participants would display on the dilemmas used in the trust games. Secondly, the target type involved just one type of "switch" decision: participants were confronted with a partner who chose the deontological option in the first iteration and the utilitarian option in the second iteration, but not with a switching partner where the decision pattern is reversed: i.e., a target making a utilitarian choice followed by a deontological one. As a result, these studies do not account for the direction of the switch and potential differences in trust inferences across two patterns of switch decisions. Finally, the dilemma that was used to measure participants' own moral preferences, as well as those used to probe trust, might be 'biased' against deontological decisions given that relatively few people prefer such decisions on these dilemmas. As noted, this might have impacted how participants evaluated partners responding in a deontological manner.

We aimed to address these shortcomings in Study 2. Additionally, we simplified our procedure. Rather than probing trust through trust games, we simply confronted participants with iterative dilemmas, probed their personal preference and then asked them how they would rate others if they were to respond to those (same) dilemmas in specific ways. This approach also allowed us to differentiate the pattern of "switching" responses. Accordingly, in these studies, participants evaluated four partners, rather than three as in Study 1. Finally, we aimed to confront participants with a more balanced set of dilemmas that drew a relatively equal proportion of deontological and utilitarian responses.

div.head: Procedure and measures
div.p: We used the same procedure for both studies. Participants first completed demographic information (age and gender). Subsequently, they completed two individual difference measures (Need for Cognition; Cacioppo et al., 1984, and Empathic Concern;Davis, 1983). Afterward, they were confronted with a series of three iterative dilemmas in Study 2a and two iterative dilemmas in Study 2b, selected through a pre-test (n = 100 North-Americans recruited through M-Turk) that demonstrated a relatively balanced distribution of deontological and utilitarian responses to these dilemmas (see supplemental materials for the verbatim dilemmas). Dilemmas were administered in random order. On each dilemma, participants were first probed for their own moral preference. They responded in a binary way and each iteration within each dilemma was administered in a sequential fashion: participants first read and responded to the first iteration, and then read and responded to the second iteration. They were then asked to rate others based on how these others had supposedly responded to that same dilemma. On each dilemma, participants were asked to rate the trustworthiness of decision-makers that had (in random order) consistently responded in a utilitarian fashion, consistently responded in a deontological fashion, had initially responded in a utilitarian fashion but had switched their response on the second iteration, and vice-versa. Participants were asked to rate trust on a 5-point scale spanning from (1) Not at all to (5) Extremely. In both studies, participants were also asked to rate warmth and competence. In study 2b, participants were additionally asked to rate warmth, competence, fairness, empathy, and caring. Again, we focus only on the results with the trust measure as those with other measures mirror the pattern we uncovered for trust. Full results for the additional measures are available in the Supplementary materials.

div.head: Results
div.p: We first looked at the pattern of participants' responses on the iterative dilemma as a measure of their own moral preference. Whereas in the dilemmas of Study 1 only a small minority of the participants across three samples gave a deontological response, we found sufficient variation in decisions across the scenarios employed in Study 2 (See Table 3). Note. We refer to 'Switch (Deo-Uti)' when participants chose to be deontologists in the first iteration of the dilemma and utilitarian in the second iteration, and vice versa in the case of 'Switch (Uti-Deo)'.

We conducted the same type of analysis as in the Study 1 series. We collapsed participants' responses for all dilemmas and analyzed them through linear mixed-effects models that included trust ratings as the dependent variable and judgment type (Utilitarian vs.
Deontological, vs. Switchers (Deotologist-Utilitarian) vs. Switchers (Utilitarian -Deotologist)),
Similarity, and the interaction between these variables as predictors. Additionally, it shows the post hoc pairwise comparisons adjusted using the Tukey method.
Whereas evidence for the similarity in Study 1 was found in most but not all comparisons, the comparisons in Study 2 indicate very robust and consistent support for the similarity effect.

Possibly, the adapted procedure testing direct similarity in judgment strengthens the effect. As depicted in Figure 2, we also found some significant differences in trust ratings between the levels of Target Type, but the patterns were not consistent across the two samples (see supplementary section for the detailed results).

div.head: Figure 2
div.p: Inferred trust as a function of partner judgment and participants' partner similarity with partner judgment.

Note. Annotations carry results of post hoc pairwise comparisons adjusted using the Tukey method. Annotations at the upper part of the plots carry comparisons across target type, and the annotations at the lower part of the plots report similarity effects within each target condition.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: Accurately ascertaining the moral character of others is critical for successfully navigating the social world. This manuscript investigated how moral judgments in sacrificial dilemmas influence trust inference in iterative decision-making. Traditional moral psychology paradigms, focused on single-shot dilemmas, may not fully capture the complexity of real-world decision-making, where choices often have cumulative effects. Our iterative approach reveals how people navigate moral complexities over time, balancing ethical considerations. Notably, 14-63% of respondents switched their responses between iterations, suggesting many adhere to equity/fairness by distributing harm. This suggests we should look beyond the utilitarian vs.
deontological distinction to better understand how people balance moral imperatives in sacrificial dilemmas (see also Bostyn & Roets, 2022;Roets et al., 2020).

Our findings highlight the importance of the similarity effect in trust inference, showing that individuals tend to trust those whose moral judgments align with their own. This effect was consistent across various dilemmas, regardless of whether participants consistently preferred deontological or utilitarian responses, or switched between them. These results challenge the notion that deontological decisions are inherently more trust-engendering than utilitarian ones.

Instead, trustworthiness appears more closely tied to perceived moral congruence between individuals than to adherence to a specific ethical doctrine. This finding sheds new light on previous research that may have overlooked the impact of moral preference alignment on trust assessments (Bostyn & Roets, 2017;Everett et al., 2016;Rom et al., 2017).

In summary, our research underscores the dynamic nature of moral decision-making and its implications for trust inference. By demonstrating the robustness of the similarity effect and nuanced trust patterns in iterative moral dilemmas, our studies provide a broader understanding of the interplay between moral judgments and social trust. These insights have significant implications for moral psychology, particularly in understanding and assessing the morality of actions in complex social settings.

div.head: Limitations, and future directions
div.p: We note limitations that suggest promising directions for future research. Firstly, our initial studies used dilemmas adapted from earlier work (Bostyn & Roets, 2022) where most participants favored the utilitarian response, possibly influencing results through descriptive norms. Study 2 used a more balanced set of dilemmas, yet the impact of assumed majority norms on judgment warrants further research. Additionally, our studies do not distinguish whether the trust ratings are influenced by the perception that a decision maker's response is (perceived as) descriptively uncommon or by the belief that the response is morally wrong. Future studies can explore this further.

Descriptive norms vary between dilemmas and cultures (Graham et al., 2016), so investigating the similarity effect in diverse cultural contexts (e.g., non-western contexts) would enhance our understanding of these mechanisms.Future research could also explore the boundaries of the similarity effect in non-sacrificial dilemmas (e.g., Gordon-Hecker et al., 2021;Singer et al., 2019) and examine whether moral identity centrality (Aquino & Reed II, 2002) influences reliance on moral similarity in trust judgments. As societies become more interconnected yet polarized, understanding trust formation in the face of diverse moral preferences (Graham et al., 2011;Shweder & Haidt, 1993) is increasingly important.
Discovering ways to overcome distrust towards those with dissimilar moral values could be particularly valuable in navigating disagreements and fostering compromise.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: The present research sheds new light on the intricate relationship between moral judgment and trust. By demonstrating the central role of similarity in moral preferences for trust inference, we offer a more nuanced understanding of the moral underpinnings of social trust. div.head: The introduction to the trust game was common across Study 1a, Study 1b, and Study 1c
div.p: A trust game is played with two players. One person plays the role of the GIVER, and the other person plays the role of the RECEIVER
The game works as follows: the GIVER gets 10 credits, and the receiver starts without any credits.

The GIVER gets to decide how many of the 10 credits they give to the RECEIVER. The GIVER can freely decide not to give anything to the RECEIVER, to give all their credits to the receiver, or something in between these two extremes.

Everything the GIVER gives to the RECEIVER will be tripled! For instance, if the GIVER gives 10 credits to the RECEIVER they will receive 30 credits in total. If the GIVER decides to give 3 credits, the RECEIVER will get a total of 9 credits.
As a final step in the game, the RECEIVER gets to decide how many of the total credits they share with the GIVER.

Importantly: these games are not happening "live". You are playing with people that have previously completed this survey and we will link up your responses afterwards. Once the experiment is over, we will calculate how many credits everyone has earned. The choices you make will help determine the bonus you will receive.

You will be asked to play five Trust games. Each game is a new game and in each game the GIVER will start off with 10 credits. Importantly, you will be paired up with a different player for each of these games.

For the first of these trust games, you will not receive any information about your partner in the game. For each of the subsequent three games, you will be provided with the responses that your partner provided to two dilemmas.
On the next page, we will first ask you to answer a simple comprehension question. We will then inform you whether you will be playing these games from the perspective of the GIVER or the receiver.

div.head: Measurement of baseline trust
div.p: 1. You are the GIVER and you are playing the current trust game against another random player. To what extent do you trust this random RECEIVER? (1-not at all; 2-a little bit, 3-an average amount, 4a lot, 5-completely)
2. How many credits would you give to this RECEIVER? (scale from 0 to 10)

div.head: Attention check question:
div.p: If you are the Giver, and you transfer all ten credits to the Receiver, how many credits will they receive?

div.head: Study 1a
div.p: Decision maker's dilemmas:

Electroshock, Iteration 1 Imagine the following scenario. You are participating in an important psychological experiment investigating how people make moral decisions. You enter the lab and see six monkeys that are hooked up to an electroshock machine. The experimenter tells you that within the next 20 seconds, 5 of the monkeys will receive a painful but non-deadly electroshock. He tells you that you can stop this from happening by pressing a button. However, pressing the button will cause the sixth monkey to be shocked instead.
Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the 5 monkeys to get a painful shock, or do you press the button, which would cause the single monkey to get a painful shock?
• Do nothing • Press the button

div.head: Electroshock, Iteration 2
div.p: The shock was delivered but the experimenter repeats the dilemma: a second shock will be delivered to the same group of five monkeys within the next twenty seconds. Once again, the only way to stop this from happening is to press the button and divert the shock to the sixth monkey, the same one as before.
Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the 5 monkeys to get a painful shock, or do you press the button, which would cause the single monkey to get a painful shock?
• Do nothing • Press the button Partners' dilemmas:

div.head: Gas
div.p: Gas, Iteration 1 Imagine the following scenario. You are the hospital administrator of a military hospital near the frontlines of an ongoing war. A bomb has just been dropped on the hospital. While no one was killed, the bomb has ruptured a gas line. The gas is leaking in a room that contains five patients recovering from severe injury. The gas is not life-threatening but it will hurt all patients and set back their recovery with a full month. The patients cannot be evacuated but you can turn on the ventilation system. The ventilation system will extract the gas from the room of the five patients but the gas will leak into another room containing only a single patient. The single patient is also recovering from a severe injury and the gas will have the same effect on the single patient, setting back recovery with a full month.

Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause 5 people to need an additional month of recovery, or do you turn on the ventilation, which would cause a single person to need an additional month of recovery?

Gas, Iteration 2 It is one month later when disaster strikes again. The hospital is bombed once more and you are confronted with the same situation: gas is leaking into the same room as before and is threatening the same 5 patients with an extra month of recovery. Once again, you can decide to turn on the ventilation to redirect the gas to the room with the same single patient instead.

Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause 5 people to need an additional month of recovery, or do you turn on the ventilation, which would cause a single person to need an additional month of recovery?
Participants in the 'Deontological' condition will read: THE RECEIVER DECIDED TO: 1. Not to do anything, causing the five patients to need an extra month of recovery.
2. Not to do anything, causing the five patients to need an extra month of recovery.

Participants in the 'Utilitarian' condition will read: THE RECEIVER DECIDED TO: 1. Intervene and turn on the ventilation causing one patient to need an extra month of recovery. 2. Intervene and turn on the ventilation causing one patient to need an extra month of recovery.
Participants in the 'Switch' condition will read: THE RECEIVER DECIDED TO: 1. Not to do anything, causing the five patients to need an extra month of recovery.

2. Intervene and turn on the ventilation causing one patient to need an extra month of recovery. Dam Dam, Iteration 1 Imagine the following scenario. You are the governor of a state that was just hit by a hurricane. The hurricane has damaged a dam causing it to be on the verge of breaking down. When the dam breaks, the water will flood a nearby town with 10.000 inhabitants. While the break cannot be averted, you could open a floodgate to divert the water to another river thus saving the city from a flood. However, doing so will flood another, smaller town with 500 inhabitants. Fortunately, you have already managed to evacuate both towns to ensure that no lives will be lost. Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause a town of 10.000 people to be flooded, or do you divert the water, which would cause a flooding in a town of 500 people.

div.head: Dam, Iteration 2
div.p: It is one year later and the damage of the hurricane from last year has been repaired. However, misfortune strikes again. Once again a hurricane has hit your state and the same dam is on the verge of breaking again and is threatening the same two cities. While construction was under way to avoid a repeat of last years' situation, these efforts were not yet completed. Both towns have been evacuated already and you are left with the same decision as before: do you do nothing and allow the larger town of 10.000 people to be flooded or do you divert the flood to the smaller town with only 500 inhabitants? Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the town of 10.000 people to be flooded, or do you divert the water, which would cause a flooding in the town of 500 people.

div.head: Hostage
div.p: Hostage, Iteration 1 Imagine the following scenario. You are a counterterrorist that has infiltrated a dangerous group of terrorists in a foreign country. The terrorists have just kidnapped a group of 4 tourists. Three of the tourists are locked up in a big cell whereas the fourth is lockup separately in a different cell. The hostages are treated well, but one night the leader of the terrorists gets drunk and flies into a fit of rage. The terrorists decides that he wants to beat up some of the hostages to release his pent-up aggression. The leader is headed towards the cell with the 3 tourists and you realize he will keep beating them until all three of them are bloody and unconscious. You realize that you could redirect his anger and suggest that he beat up the single hostage instead. This would satiate his bloodlust sufficiently to ensure that he leaves the group of three hostages alone.
Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the terrorist to beat up the group of 3 tourists, or do you redirect his anger, which would cause the terrorist to beat up the single tourist.

div.head: Hostage, Iteration 2
div.p: It is now two weeks later and although no further beatings have occurred, none of the hostages have been released. One night, the terrorist leader gets drunk again, and decides he wants another round of beatings. Once again, the terrorist is headed towards the cell with the same 3 tourists as before and you are certain he will beat up all three. However, once again, you realize that you could redirect him to the cell with the single tourist instead and that once that beating is done, he will break out of his current bloodlust.
Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the terrorist to beat up the group of 3 tourists, or do you redirect his anger, which would cause the terrorist to beat up the single tourist.

div.head: Measuring Trust
div.p: You are the GIVER and you are playing the current trust game against a random other player. To what extent do you trust this random RECEIVER?
(1= Not at all; 5= Completely) How many credits would you give to this RECEIVER? (0 to 10 on a slider scale)

div.head: Study 1b
div.p: Note: All the participants of the study were presented with Iteration 1 of the dilemma. The version of the Iteration 2 dilemmas were based on the between-subjects experimental condition (Experimental vs. Control).

div.head: Electroshock 2
div.p: Electroshock, Iteration 1 Imagine the following scenario. You are participating in an important psychological experiment investigating how people make moral decisions. You enter the lab and see six monkeys that are hooked up to an electroshock machine. The experimenter tells you that within the next 20 seconds, 5 of the monkeys will receive a painful but non-deadly electroshock. He tells you that you can stop this from happening by pressing a button. However, pressing the button will cause the sixth monkey to be shocked instead.
Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the 5 monkeys to get a painful shock, or do you press the button, which would cause the single monkey to get a painful shock?

• Do nothing • Press the button Electroshock, Iteration 2: Experimental The shock was delivered but the experimenter repeats the dilemma: a second shock will be delivered to the same group of five monkeys within the next twenty seconds. Once again, the only way to stop this from happening is to press the button and divert the shock to the sixth monkey, the same one as before.
Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the 5 monkeys to get a painful shock, or do you press the button, which would cause the single monkey to get a painful shock?

• Do nothing • Press the button Electroshock, Iteration 2: Control The shock was delivered and the experimenter takes you into another room. In the other room are six different monkeys, also hooked up to electroshock machines. The experiment repeats the dilemma: a shock will be delivered to five of the new monkeys within the next twenty seconds Once again, the only way to stop this from happening is to press the button and divert the shock to the sixth new monkey.
Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause the 5 new monkeys to get a painful shock, or do you press the button, which would cause the sixth new monkey to get a painful shock?
• Do nothing
• Press the button

div.head: Gas
div.p: Gas, Iteration 1 Imagine the following scenario. You are the hospital administrator of a military hospital near the frontlines of an ongoing war. A bomb has just been dropped on the hospital. While no one was killed, the bomb has ruptured a gas line. The gas is leaking in a room that contains five patients recovering from severe injury. The gas is not life-threatening but it will hurt all patients and set back their recovery with a full month. The patients cannot be evacuated but you can turn on the ventilation system. The ventilation system will extract the gas from the room of the five patients but the gas will leak into another room containing only a single patient. The single patient is also recovering from a severe injury and the gas will have the same effect on the single patient, setting back recovery with a full month.

Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause 5 people to need an additional month of recovery, or do you turn on the ventilation, which would cause a single person to need an additional month of recovery?

Gas, Iteration 2: Experimental It is one month later when disaster strikes again. The hospital is bombed once more and you are confronted with the same situation: gas is leaking into the same room as before and is threatening the same 5 patients with an extra month of recovery. Once again, you can decide to turn on the ventilation to redirect the gas to the room with the same single patient instead.

Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause 5 people to need an additional month of recovery, or do you turn on the ventilation, which would cause a single person to need an additional month of recovery?

Gas, Iteration 2: Control It is one month later when disaster strikes again. Another wing in the hospital is bombed, and you are confronted with a similar situation: gas is leaking into a room in a different wing of the hospital and is threatening another group of 5 different patients with an extra month of recovery. Once again, you can decide to turn on the ventilation to redirect the gas to another room that contains a different single patient instead.

Do you decide not to do anything, which would cause 5 people to need an additional month of recovery, or do you turn on the ventilation, which would cause a single person to need an additional month of recovery?

Participants in the 'Deontological' condition will read: THE RECEIVER DECIDED TO: 1. Not to do anything, causing the five patients to need an extra month of recovery. 2. Not to do anything, causing the five patients to need an extra month of recovery.
Participants in the 'Utilitarian' condition will read: THE RECEIVER DECIDED TO: 1. Intervene and turn on the ventilation causing one patient to need an extra month of recovery.
2. Intervene and turn on the ventilation causing one patient to need an extra month of recovery.
Participants in the 'Switch' condition will read: THE RECEIVER DECIDED TO: 1. Not to do anything, causing the five patients to need an extra month of recovery.
2. Intervene and turn on the ventilation causing one patient to need an extra month of recovery.

div.head: Measures for exploratory analysis: Participants' social inference of their game partners
div.p: • How much do you think altruistic, empathic motives drove the receiver's decisions to the dilemmas? (Not at all = 1; Very much = 7) • How competent do you think the receiver is? (1= Not at all competent, 4= neutral; 7 = Extremely competent)

• How cold or warm do you think the receiver is? (1= Extremely cold, 4= neutral; 7 = Extremely warm) • How coward or brave do you think the receiver is? (1= Extremely coward, 4= neutral; 7 = Extremely brave) • As a person, how rigid or flexible do you think the receiver is? (Extremely rigid = 1;
Extremely flexible = 7) • To what extent do you think the receiver is willing to experience discomfort to bring about greater good to others? (1= Not a lot; 7 = To a great extent)

div.head: Study 2a
div.p: Technical problems

Iteration 1 Imagine the following situation. You are a manager at an electricity supplier. You have just received a call from a local company that is suffering from an electricity outage. Seven employees are without light, power or internet connection and are unable to continue their work until this problem is solved. You realize that fixing this problem will take at least a week, causing the company to be non-active. You see one quick solution. You could reroute the electricity from another nearby business. The nearby business has only two employees and while that business will have to shut down for a week instead, this would minimize the damage caused by the outage. What do you decide to do?

A: I decide to do nothing, causing the business with seven employees to be non-active B: I decide to reroute the electricity, causing the business with two employees to be non-active Iteration 2 A couple of weeks later you receive a call from the same company of seven employees saying that they are suffering from an electricity outage yet again and are unable to continue work. Just like the previous time, you realize fixing their problem will take a week. However, just like before, you have the option to reroute the electricity from that other business with the two employees and while that business will have to shut down for a week instead, this would minimize the damage caused by the outage. What do you decide to do this time? Do you decide to do nothing, which will cause the business with seven employees to be non-active, or do you reroute the electricity and the business with two employees will be non-active?
A: I decide to do nothing, causing the business with seven employees to be non-active B: I decide to reroute the electricity, causing the business with two employees to be non-active

div.head: Animal shelter
div.p: Iteration 1 Imagine the following situation. You are working at an animal shelter. The shelter is taking care of so many animals there is no room left. Three small new dogs have just arrived but you have no room to give them shelter inside. You can keep them in an outside courtyard but you know the night will be very cold. You notice that you can make room by dragging Lassie, a good-natured and kind dog but also the largest animal in the shelter, outside, and give her cage to the three smaller dogs instead. What do you decide to do? Do you decide to do nothing, leaving the three smaller dogs outside in the cold, or do you drag Lassie outside?

A: I decide to do nothing and leave the three dogs outside B: I decide to drag Lassie outside Iteration 2 It is two weeks later. The three smaller dogs had been adopted, but unfortunately for them, they were just returned to the shelter because they were not a good match with the family that adopted them. However, the shelter is still full and once again you have to make a choice, the same as a few weeks ago. You could put the three smaller dogs outside in the courtyard, or drag Lassie, the larger dog, outside and give her cage to the three smaller dogs. What do you decide to do this time? Do you decide to do nothing, leaving the three smaller dogs outside in the cold, or do you drag Lassie outside?
A: I decide to do nothing and leave the three dogs outside B: I decide to drag Lassie outside

div.head: Car repair shop
div.p: Iteration 1 Imagine the following situation. You are working in a car repair shop. Six cars were brought into your garage for repair this week. You have each owner's permission to complete the repairs with used parts. You have just finished repairing the car that was brought in a few days before the others when you get a call that the delivery of the used parts you were planning on using for the remaining cars will be delayed by 10 days. This is inconvenient but you realize that you could repair all five remaining cars by harvesting the necessary parts from the car you just finished. Doing so would allow you to repair all five cars more quickly but will cause the repair of the first car to be delayed by the 10 days it will take to have the new parts delivered. What do you decide to do? Do you decide to do nothing and wait for the spare parts to arrive, leaving five people waiting for their car for another 10 days, or do you harvest the necessary parts of the one car which will ensure that only one person has to wait for 10 days to get their car fixed?

A: I decide to do nothing, causing five persons will have to wait 10 days for their car B: I decide to harvest the necessary parts, causing one person will have to wait 10 days for their car Iteration 2 A year later, the same people as last year came with their cars for their annual inspection. While the repairs from last year are holding up well, other problems have emerged for each of the cars. Like before, you have the permission of each owner to complete the repairs with used parts. Strangely enough, the exact same thing as the year before happens: you have just finished repairing the car that was brought in a few days before the others and that you also finished first last year when you get a call that the delivery of the used parts you were planning on using for the remaining cars will be delayed by 10 days. This is inconvenient, but you have the same option as last year: you can harvest the necessary parts from the car you just finished and fix the five remaining cars. Doing so would allow you to repair all five cars more quickly but will cause the repair of the first car to be delayed by the 10 days it will take to have the new parts delivered.

What do you decide to do this time? Do you decide to do nothing and wait for the spare parts to arrive, leaving five people waiting for their car for another 10 days, or do you harvest the necessary parts of the one car which will ensure that only one person has to wait for 10 days to get their car fixed?

A: I decide to do nothing, causing five persons will have to wait 10 days for their car B: I decide to harvest the necessary parts, causing one person will have to wait 10 days for their car It is two weeks later. The three smaller dogs had been adopted, but unfortunately for them, they were just returned to the shelter because they were not a good match with the family that adopted them. However, the shelter is still full and once again you have to make a choice, the same as a few weeks ago. You could put the three smaller dogs outside in the courtyard, or drag Lassie, the larger dog, outside and give her cage to the three smaller dogs. What do you decide to do this time? Do you decide to do nothing, leaving the three smaller dogs outside in the cold, or do you drag Lassie outside?

All the participants in Study 1a read Same-victim version of the dilemmas. Participants in the Study 1b were allocated either to Same-victim or Different-victim versions of the dilemmas. Participants in Study 1c were allocated to one of the One-shot, Same-victim, Different-victim versions of the dilemmas.

The primary difference between Study 1a, 1b, and 1c was the inclusion of additional control conditions in Studies 1b and 1c. More specifically: Study 1a only involved confronting participants with iterative sacrificial dilemmas that involved the same set of targets on each iteration. Study 1b included these same dilemmas in the main condition, but also included a condition in which the iterative sacrificial dilemmas involved different targets for each iteration. Study 1c included all conditions from Study 1b and included yet another between-subject condition involving single-shot sacrificial dilemmas. All conditions in Studies 1b and 1c were run between subjects.

div.head: Study 1a Method Participants and procedure
div.p: We recruited 147 North American participants from the CloudResearch platform of which 83 identified as female and 63 identified as male. Participants had an average age of 34.91 (SD = 17.61).

Participants were asked to complete basic demographic information (age & gender) and were subsequently confronted with two tasks. The first task was to answer an iterative dilemma task as a decision-maker in which they had to pursue had to decide which option they would pursue. The second task was to play a series of four trust games. The first of these trust games was an uninformed trust game, aimed at measuring participants' baseline levels of trust and cooperation. The following three trust games were informed trust games in which participants were provided with some information about their partner in the trust game: their decision on an iterative sacrificial dilemma. All the iterative dilemmas involved the same victim scenario. Once all trust games were completed participants were debriefed.

div.head: Materials
div.p: Participants as decision-makers answered an iterative electroshock dilemma. The electroshock dilemma described a hypothetical situation in which 6 monkeys were hooked up to an electroshock machine. Participants were told that a single monkey would be shocked but this could be averted by shocking the five other monkeys instead. The participants chose between a response option to minimize overall harm and a response option to refrain from personally doing harm. Participants decided for the first iteration and the dilemma is repeated and another shock is to be delivered to the same targets.

Following the first task participants were invited to play a series of four trust games. Before playing their first trust game, participants were explained how trust games work. More specifically, participants were explained that each trust game has two players: a trustor and a trustee. Participants were told that the trustor would receive 10 credits and that they were free to decide how many of these credits to give to the trustee. They were told that all credits given to the trustee would be tripled and that afterward, the trustee was free to decide how many of the credits they wished to return. Trustors could thus maximize their earnings by endowing the trustee with a large number of credits but in doing so they risked losing out on earnings if they decided to endow an untrustworthy trustee with their credits. Participants were told that they would play a series of these games and that they would be matched with a different partner on each game. Participants were told they would not be playing these games live but that their responses would be randomly matched to those of other participants after the study was completed. We told participants that they would play games as either the trustor or the trustee but in reality, all participants played all games from the perspective of the trustor.

After receiving instructions on the trust game, participants were asked two comprehension questions. First, they were asked to imagine a situation where the trustor transferred 5 credits to the trustee and asked how many credits (if any) the trustee should return if the trustee wants to maximize their earnings. Participants were asked to respond using a multiple-choice format and were presented with four choice options: returning 0, 5, 10 or 15 credits. Subsequently, they were asked how many credits a trustee would receive if a trustor endows them with 10 credits and had to select the correct response from the options: 10, 20, 30, or 40 credits.

After completing the comprehension checks participants started playing the trust games. First, they played an uninformed trust game. Participants were told they were matched up with a random other participant about whom they received no information. They were asked to rate how much they trusted this random other person using a five-point Likert scale spanning from (1) Not at all to (5) Completely. They were also asked how many credits they wanted to endow this random other person with, using a sliding scale spanning from 0 to 10 credits.

Subsequently, they played an additional three informed trust games. In each of these trust games, participants were shown an iterative dilemma with the same targets across two iterations and were told what their supposed partner's response was to this sacrificial dilemma. Participants were presented with a partner who responded in a deontological fashion across two iterations, a partner who responded in a utilitarian fashion across two iterations, and a partner who switched from a deontological choice from the first iteration to a utilitarian choice in the section iteration, we labeled as "switcher".

The dilemmas presented as part of the informed trust games are drawn from three iterative sacrificial dilemmas. The first dilemma described a situation in which a gas leak in a hospital threatened to lengthen the recovery time of five injured patients with an additional month. Again, this outcome could be averted only by redirecting the harm to a single injured patient instead. The second dilemma described an overflooding dam in which the decision maker faces a choice: allow a dam break to flood a town of 10,000 people or divert the water to flood a smaller town of 500. The third dilemma involved a hostage situation where the choice was between not intervening, leading to harm for the hostages, or redirecting the harm to a single hostage. Accordingly, each dilemma contrasted a response option to minimize overall harm with a response option to refrain from personally doing harm.

div.head: Results
div.p: The first task involved participants answering an iterative dilemma taking the role of a decisionmaker. Only a large proportion of participants decided in favor of sacrificial harm on the first iteration of the electroshock dilemma (82.3%). However, when confronted with the second iteration, a decreased proportion of participants condoned the sacrificial harm: 34.0% of participants favored sacrificial harm (See Fig. S1). A McNemar test for paired proportion confirmed this difference was statistically significant (χ2(1) = 52.69, p < .001).

div.head: Figure S1
div.p: Proportion of "utilitarian responses" for each iteration. Error bars denote the 95% confidence interval around each estimate.

We ran two sets of mixed-effects regression models with trust ratings and credit transfer as outcome variables. In both models, we included the partner's choice and the similarity of choice between the partner and the participant (yes vs. no). Additionally, we included participants' baseline levels of trust or cooperation, and dilemma identifier (Dam vs. Hostage vs. Gas) as control variables. Participant IDs were included as random intercepts.

div.head: Table S3
div.p: Results of linear regression analysis with trust ratings as outcome measure. Categorical variables were dummy coded. The results of the analysis demonstrate one clear pattern. There is support for the similarity effect: participants favored the partners who made similar decisions as them. On average, utilitarian partners were trusted more than deontologist partners.

div.head: Participants and procedure
div.p: We recruited 577 North American participants from the CloudResearch platform. Based on the registered exclusion criteria we excluded 25 participants who indicated low proficiency in English (self-report < 5, on a 1-7 scale), 3 participants who self-reported not being serious about filling in the survey (self-report < 4, on a 1-5 scale), and 49 participants who failed any of the two comprehension checks. We ended up with 500 participants of which 276 identified as female, identified as male, and 2 others. Participants had an average age of 40.84 (SD = 12.36).

Participants first consented to take part in the study and were subsequently confronted with two tasks. Participants were evenly allocated to a control condition or the same victim condition. The same victim condition -similar to the scenarios of Study 1-described the same targets were affected as part of iteration 2, whereas the control condition described scenarios in which the second iteration of the dilemmas involved a new set of targets.

The first task was to answer an iterative dilemma task as a decision-maker in which they had to pursue had to decide which option they would pursue. The second task was to play a series of four trust games. The first of these trust games was an uninformed trust game, aimed at measuring participants' baseline levels of trust and cooperation. The following three trust games were informed trust games in which participants were provided with some information about their partner in the trust game: their decision on an iterative sacrificial dilemma. All the iterative dilemmas involved the same victim scenario. Once all trust games were completed participants reported their age and gender and were debriefed.

div.head: Study design
div.p: The study employed 2 (Type of iterative dilemma: Different Victim Iterative dilemma vs. Same Victim iterative dilemma) × 3 (Partner's moral decision: Utilitarian, Deontological, Switch 3 ). The type of iterative dilemma condition was a between-subjects factor (251 allocated to the same victim condition and 249 participants allocated to different victim condition), and the Partner's moral decision was a within-subject factor.

div.head: Results
div.p: The first task involved participants answering an iterative dilemma taking the role of a decisionmaker. We compared the proportion of 'switchers' between both conditions. A one-sided proportion test (as per our preregistration) confirmed the expected increase in the proportion of switchers in the experimental condition compared to the control condition, χ 2 (1) = 96.05, p < .001 (see Figure #).

div.head: Figure S2
div.p: Proportion of "switch responses" for each condition. Error bars denote the 95% confidence interval around each estimate.

We ran two sets of mixed-effects regression models with trust ratings and credit transfer as outcome variables. In both models, we included the partner's choice and the similarity of choice between the partner, the participant (yes vs. no), and interaction between two terms as fixed effect predictors. Additionally, we included participants' baseline levels of trust or cooperation as a control variable. Participant IDs were included as random intercepts. The results across the two dependent variables are very similar. Besides we conducted additional analysis with other six measures of partner's personality. The results are very similar. Additionally, we looked if the trust ratings in a switch partner were similar across the control condition vs. the same victim condition. We found that switch partners were trusted less in the control condition (t (497.5) = -2.46, p = 0.014; Cohen d = -0.22, 95% CI [-0.40 -0.04])

div.head: Table S5

div.head: Participants and procedure
div.p: We recruited 804 North American participants from the CloudResearch platform. Based on the registered exclusion criteria we excluded 1 participant who indicated low proficiency in English (self-report < 5, on a 1-7 scale), 8 participants who self-reported not being serious about filling in the survey (self-report < 4, on a 1-5 scale), 1 participant who completed the study within 2 minutes, and 71 participants who failed any of the two comprehension checks. We ended up with 723 participants of 326 identified as female and 389 identified as male, and 8 were noted as others/do not want to disclose. Participants had an average age of 44.10(SD = 13.85).

Participants first consented to take part in the study and were subsequently confronted with two tasks. Participants were evenly allocated to one of the three between-subject conditions: Different victim Iterative vs. Same victim iterative vs. Single-shot dilemmas condition. The same victim condition -similar to the scenarios of Study 1-described the same targets were affected as part of iteration 2, whereas the different victim conditions described scenarios in which the second iteration of the dilemmas involved a new set of targets. The single-shot dilemmas did not have an iteration 2.

The first task was to answer a dilemma as a decision-maker in which they had to pursue had to decide which option they would pursue. The second task was to play a series of four trust games. The first of these trust games was an uninformed trust game, aimed at measuring participants' baseline levels of trust and cooperation. The following three trust games were informed trust games in which participants were provided with some information about their partner in the trust game: their decision on an iterative sacrificial dilemma. All the iterative dilemmas involved the same victim scenario. Once all trust games were completed participants reported their age and gender and were debriefed.

div.head: Study design
div.p: The study employed 3 (Type of iterative dilemma 4 : Different Victim Iterative dilemma vs. Same Victim iterative dilemma vs. Single-shot dilemma) × 3 (Partner's moral decision: Utilitarian, Deontological, Switch 5 ). The type of iterative dilemma condition was a between-subjects factor, and the Partner's moral decision was a within-subject factor. The participants in the 'Single-shot dilemma' condition were presented with two partner decision dilemmas (Utilitarian and Deontological decisions).

div.head: Materials
div.p: The same set of dilemmas from Study 1 was involved in Study 2 with two variations: control condition vs. same victim condition. Besides two measures of trust inferences, we also measured participant's impression of the trust game partner on a variety of personality attributes: altruism, competence, warmth, bravery, flexibility, and willingness to experience discomfort.

div.head: Results
div.p: We first looked at responses within iterative dilemma conditions in the first task that involved participants taking the role of a decision-maker. We compared the proportion of 'switchers' between conditions. A one-sided proportion test confirmed the expected increase in the proportion of switchers in the experimental condition compared to the control condition, χ 2 (1) = 83.34, p < .001 (see Figure #).

div.head: Figure S3
div.p: Proportion of "switch responses" for each condition. Error bars denote the 95% confidence interval around each estimate.

We ran two sets of mixed-effects regression models with trust ratings and credit transfer as outcome variables. In both models, we included the partner's choice and the similarity of choice between the partner, the participant (yes vs. no), and the condition (control vs. same victim) as fixed effect predictors. Additionally, we included participants' baseline levels of trust or cooperation as a control variable. Participant IDs were included as random intercepts. The results across the two dependent variables are very similar. Besides we conducted additional analysis with other six measures of partner's personality. The results are very similar.

div.head: Table S19
div.p: Results of linear regression analysis with trust ratings as outcome measure. Categorical variables were dummy coded. Significance codes: '' 0.001, '' 0.01, '' 0.05.

div.head: Table S21
div.p: Pairwise Comparisons of similarity by partner type on Trust ratings DV.

div.head: Participants and procedure
div.p: We recruited 200 North American participants from the CloudResearch platform of which 326 identified as female and 389 identified as male. Participants had an average age of 36.05 (SD = 10.95).

We started our survey with two demographic questions (age and gender). Next, we included the shortened six-statement version of the 'Need for Cognition ' (Petty et al., 1984) and the 'Empathic Concern' (Davis, 1983) scales for exploratory purposes. For the 'Need for Cognition' scale, the participants had to indicate how characteristic the following statement applied to themselves. The items were scored on a scale from one to five (1 = Extremely uncharacteristic, 5 = Extremely characteristic). An example of a statement is: "I would prefer complex to simple problems.". For the 'Empathic Concern' scale participants had to indicate to what extent the following statements described them. The items were scored on a scale from one to five (1 = Does not describe me well, 5 = Describes me well). An example of a statement is: "I often have tender, concerned feelings for people less fortunate than me."

The three dilemmas we used in our study were taken from the pilot study and then adapted to an iterative version. For each of the three dilemmas, the participant responded to a dilemma as a decision-maker. Subsequently, the participant was told that he or she was matched with four other participants. The other persons were indicated by a code which was a random combination of letters and numbers. However, these were fictional individuals whom the participant did not know. The participant and the fictional individual had four answer combinations on the dilemma (Utilitarian, Switch (Deontological-Utilitarian), Switch (Utilitarian -Deontological), Deontologist). Based on the information about the fictional individual they were asked to rate the person on warmth, competence, and trust. The ratings were presented as follows: 'How warm/competent/trustworthy is this person?'. The participants could answer with Not at all, Slightly, Somewhat, Moderately, and Extremely.

div.head: Study design
div.p: The study employed 3 (Iterative dilemma version: Technical problems, Animal shelter, Car repair shop) × 3 (Partner's moral decision: Utilitarian, Switch (Deontological-Utilitarian), Switch (Utilitarian -Deontological), Deontologist). Both the Iterative dilemma version and the Partner's moral decision were within-subject factors.

div.head: Materials
div.p: We wanted to explicitly take this into account by developing dilemmas that included a relatively balanced distribution of participants who preferred the deontological option and participants who preferred the utilitarian option. We came up with ten dilemmas, that could later be adapted to iterative dilemmas which were then used in a pilot study to investigate how people would respond to them. We recruited 100 North American participants by using Amazon Mechanical Turk. We calculated the percentages of how many participants chose the deontological option and how many the utilitarian option for each dilemma. In the current study, we picked three of the ten dilemmas which were closest to a 50/50 distribution of deontological and utilitarian answers.

div.head: Results
div.p: We first looked at responses within each of the three iterative dilemmas taking the role of a decision-maker. We contrasted the proportion of utilitarian decisions across iteration 1 and 2. The contrast was significant in one of the dilemma versions (see Fig. #).

div.head: Figure S4
div.p: Proportion of "utilitarian responses" for each iteration. Error bars denote the 95% confidence interval around each estimate.

We ran three sets of mixed-effects regression models with trust, warmth, and competence ratings as outcome variables. In all three models, we included the partner's choice the similarity of choice between the partner and the participant (yes vs. no), and interaction between two terms as fixed effect predictors. Additionally, we included participants' dilemma identifier as a control variable. Participant ID was included as a random intercept. The results across the three dependent variables are very similar. Besides we conducted additional analysis with other six measures of partner's personality.

div.head: Table S33
div.p: Results of linear regression analysis with trust ratings as the outcome measure. Marginal R 2 / Conditional R 2 0.172 / 0.445

div.head: Participants and procedure
div.p: We recruited we recruited 399 first-year Ghent University psychology students of which 329 identified as female and 62 identified as male. Participants had an average age of 18.99 (SD = 3.54).

The participants first saw the informed consent followed by two demographic questions namely age and gender. Next, they had to answer 18 items from the 'Need for Cognition' scale (Petty et al., 1984), and 7 items from the 'Empathic Concern' scale (Davis, 1983). In the second part of the survey, they were confronted with an iterative dilemma task. Next, they had to answer 18 items from the 'Need for Cognition' scale (Petty et al., 1984), and 7 items from the 'Empathic Concern' scale (Davis, 1983). In the second part of the survey, they were confronted with an iterative dilemma task. Two dilemmas from Study 4 were selected, namely the 'Animal shelter' and 'Car repair shop' dilemma. The setup of the questionnaire was the same as in Study One, but because the participants were native Dutch speakers, we translated the questionnaire from Study 4 into Dutch.

div.head: Study design
div.p: The study employed 2 (Iterative dilemma version: Animal shelter, Car repair shop) × 3 (Partner's moral decision: Utilitarian, Switch (Deontological-Utilitarian), Switch (Utilitarian -Deontological), Deontologist). Both the Dilemma version and the Partner's moral decision were within-subject factors.

div.head: Results
div.p: We first looked at responses within each of the three iterative dilemmas taking the role of a decision-maker. We contrasted the proportion of utilitarian decisions across iterations 1 and 2. The contrast was significant across both dilemmas (see Fig. #).

div.head: Figure S5
div.p: Proportion of "utilitarian responses" for each iteration. Error bars denote the 95% confidence interval around each estimate.

We ran six sets of mixed-effects regression models with trust, warmth, competence, fairness, empathy, and caring personality ratings as outcome variables. In all three models, we included the partner's choice the similarity of choice between the partner and the participant (yes vs. no), and the interaction between two terms as fixed effect predictors. Dilemma identifier and Participant ID were included as random intercepts. The results across the three dependent variables are very similar. Besides we conducted additional analysis with other six measures of partner's personality.

body.note: Study 1 and Study 2 were planned and conducted simultaneously and independently by two research teams. As a result, three of the studies were not pre-registered.

We did not collect any data on the racial composition of the sample in Study 1a. Study 1b and Study 1c sample collection included additional control conditions (not part of this table) whose results mirror those reported in the main text. Please refer to the supplementary materials section for details.
The electroshock dilemma will be used to measure participants' own moral preferences, whereas other three dilemmas will be used to manipulate/describe partner's moral decisions.
The electroshock dilemma will be used to measure participants' own moral preferences, whereas other three dilemmas will be used to manipulate/describe partner's moral decisions.

Switch condition: The participants in the Switch condition will be described of a partner who choose follow a deontological preference and a utilitarian decision across iterations of the moral dilemma.

237 participants were allocated to the same victim condition, 237 participants were allocated to different victim conditions, and 249 were allocated to the single shot dilemmas condition.5 Switch condition: The participants in the Switch condition will be described of a partner who choose to follow a deontological preference and a utilitarian decision across iterations of the moral dilemma.
